(County of Edinburgh until 1890) || ''Meadhan Lodainn/Labhdaidh'' || |- | [[Moray (county)|County of Moray]]
(also known as Elginshire until 1918) || ''Moireibh'' || |- | [[Nairnshire]] || ''Siorrachd Inbhir Narann'' || |- | [[Orkney]] || ''Arcaibh'' || |- | [[Peeblesshire]] || ''Siorrachd nam Puballan'' || |- | [[Perthshire]] || ''Siorrachd Pheairt'' || |- | [[Renfrewshire (historic)|Renfrewshire]] || ''Siorrachd Rinn Friù'' || |- | [[Ross and Cromarty]] || ''Ros is Cromba'' || |- | [[Roxburghshire]] || ''Siorrachd Rosbruig'' || |- | [[Selkirkshire]] || ''Siorrachd Shailcirc'' || |- | [[Shetland|Zetland]]
(Shetland) || ''Sealtainn'' || |- | [[Stirlingshire]] || ''Siorrachd Shruighlea'' || |- | [[Sutherland]] || ''Cataibh'' || |- | [[West Lothian]]
([[Linlithgowshire]] until 1924) || ''Lodain/Labhdaidh an Iar'' || |- | [[Wigtownshire]] || ''Siorrachd Bhaile na h-Ùige'' || |- |} ==Canada== {{main|Canadian Gaelic}} {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} Names in '''Cape Breton Island''' ''(Eilean Cheap Breatainn)'' *Broad Cove: ''An Caolas Leathann'' *[[Inverness County, Nova Scotia|Glendale]]: ''Bràigh na h-Aibhneadh'' *[[Inverness, Nova Scotia|Inverness]]: ''Baile Inbhir Nis'' or ''An Sithean'' *[[Judique, Nova Scotia|Judique]]: ''Siùdaig'' *[[Mabou, Nova Scotia|Mabou]]: ''Màbu'' or ''An Drochaid'' *[[Margaree River|Southwest Margaree]]: ''Bràigh na h-Aibhne'' *[[Whycocomagh, Nova Scotia|Whycocomagh]]: ''Hogamah'' *[[Baddeck, Nova Scotia|Baddeck]]: ''Badaig'' *[[Victoria County, Nova Scotia|Iona]]: ''Sanndraigh'' *The North Shore: ''An Cladach a Tuath'' *[[St. Ann's, Nova Scotia|St Ann's]]: ''Baile Anna'' *[[Christmas Island, Nova Scotia|Christmas Island]]: ''Eilean na Nollaig'' *[[Big Beach, Nova Scotia|Big Beach]]: ''An Tràigh Mhòr'' *[[List of communities in the Cape Breton Regional Municipality|Grand Mira]]: ''A' Mhira Mhòr'' *[[Big Pond, Nova Scotia|Big Pond]]: ''Am Pòn Mòr'' *[[Loch Lomond, Nova Scotia|Loch Lomond]]: ''Loch Laomainn'' *[[Marion Bridge, Nova Scotia|Marion Bridge]]: ''Drochaid Mhira'' *[[Sydney, Nova Scotia|Sydney]]: ''Baile Shidni'' *[[Richmond County, Nova Scotia|Grand River]]: ''Abhainn Mhòr'' *[[Port Hastings, Nova Scotia|Port Hastings]]: ''Còbh a' Phlàstair'' *[[Port Hawkesbury, Nova Scotia|Port Hawkesbury]]: ''Baile a' Chlamhain'' or ''An Gut'' {{col-break}} {{col-2}} Names in '''mainland Nova Scotia''' ''(Tìr Mór na h-Albann Nuaidh)'' *[[Antigonish, Nova Scotia|Antigonish]] ''Am Baile Mòr'' *[[Arisaig, Nova Scotia|Arisaig]] ''Àrasaig'' *Giant's Lake: ''Loch an Fhamhair'' *[[City of Halifax|Halifax]] ''Halafacs'' *[[New Glasgow, Nova Scotia|New Glasgow]] ''Am Baile Beag'' or ''Glaschu Nuadh'' Elsewhere in '''Canada''' *[[Glengarry County, Ontario|Glengarry County, Ont.]] ''Siorrachd Gleanna Garadh'' *[[Bruce County, Ontario|Bruce County, Ont.]] ''Siorramachd Bhruis'' *[[Nova Scotia]] ''Alba Nuadh'' or ''Alba Ùr'' *[[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]] ''Talamh an Èisg'' or ''Eilein a' Trosg'' *[[Prince Edward Island]]: ''Eilean Eòin'' or ''An t-Eilean Dearg''; ''Eilean a' Phrionnsa'' *[[Lot 60, Prince Edward Island|Lewes, Prince Edward Island]] ''An Tuirc'' *[[Calgary|Calgary, Alta.]] ''Calgarraidh'' *[[Stornoway, Quebec]] ''Steòrnabhagh'' {{col-end}} ==New Zealand== The southern [[South Island]] of New Zealand was settled by the [[Free Church of Scotland (1843–1900)|Free Church of Scotland]], and many of its placenames are of Scottish Gaelic origin (including some directly named for places in Scotland): *[[Lake Aviemore]] – ''an Aghaidh Mhòr'' *[[Balclutha, New Zealand|Balclutha]] – ''Baile Chluaidh'' *[[Lake Benmore]] – ''Beinn Mhor'' *[[Clutha River]] – ''Cluaidh'' *[[Clyde, New Zealand|Clyde]] – ''Cluaidh'' *[[Dunedin]] – ''Dùn Èideann'' *[[Inch Clutha]] – ''Innis Chluaidh'' *[[Invercargill]] – ''Inbhir'', plus the surname Cargill *[[Kinloch, New Zealand|Kinloch]] – ''Ceann Loch'' *[[Oban, New Zealand|Oban]] – ''an t-Òban'' *[[Water of Leith, New Zealand|Water of Leith]] – ''Lìte'' The placename [[Strath Taieri]] combines the Gaelic ''Srath'' with the [[Māori language|Māori]] river name [[Taieri River|Taieri]]. Gaelic names elsewhere in New Zealand include the following: *[[Huntly, New Zealand|Huntly]] – ''Hunndaidh'' *[[Kinleith]] – ''Ceann Lìte'' *[[Lagmhor]] – ''Lag Mhor'' == Other regions == *[[Cornwall]] – ''A’ Chòrn'' *[[Gibraltar]] – ''Giobraltair'' *[[Yorkshire]] – ''Siorramachd Ioirc'' == Cities outside Scotland == *[[Athens]] – ''Baile na h-Àithne'' *[[Belfast]] – ''Beul Feirste'' *[[Bergen]] – ''Boirbhe'' *[[Berwick-upon-Tweed|Berwick]] – ''Bearaig'' *[[Brussels]] – ''Am Bruiseal'' *[[Carlisle, Cumbria|Carlisle]] – ''Cathair Luail'' *[[Derry]] – ''Doire Chaluim Chille'' *[[Dublin]] – ''Baile Àth Cliath'' *[[Galway]] – ''Baile na Gailbhinn'' *[[Liverpool]] – ''Poll a' Ghruthain'' *[[London]] – ''Lunnainn'' *[[Manchester]] – ''Manchain'' *[[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]] – ''An Caisteal Nuadh'' *[[Oxford]] – ''Àth nan Damh'' *[[Rome]] – ''An Ròimh'' *[[York]] – ''Eabhraig'' == Continents == *[[Africa]] – ''Afraga'' ==Countries== ===Asia=== ====Far East==== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin: 1em 1em;" ! scope="col" | English ! scope="col" | Scottish Gaelic ! scope="col" | Native Name |- | {{flag|Brunei}} || ''Brùnaigh'' || Brunei |- | {{flag|Cambodia}} || ''Cambuidea'' || កម្ពុជា

page.title: List of countries by total renewable water resources

revision.comment: /* Renewable Internal Freshwater Resources per capita */ fix table and indices in table
revision.text:
{{short description|list of countries by total renewable water resources mostly based on The World Factbook}} This is a '''list of countries by total [[renewable resource|renewable]] [[water resources]]''' mostly based on [[The World Factbook]].{{cite web|last1=Factbook|first1=The World|title=Total Renewable Water Resources|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2201.html|website=The World Factbook|accessdate=2015-06-20|ref=FactBook|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150612123716/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2201.html|archivedate=2015-06-12|df=}}{{cite web|title= World Water Resources by country|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/005/y4473e/y4473e08.htm#TopOfPage|website=FAO|accessdate=21 August 2018}} This entry provides the long-term average water availability for a country in [[cubic kilometer]]s from precipitation, [[groundwater recharge]], and surface inflows from surrounding countries. Fresh and unpolluted water accounts for 0.003% of total water available globally.{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Lttb1qPh4Z8C|title=; David Katz (2006)|last=Peter Gleick; Heather Cooley|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} == [[Water resources|Water resource]] == Main article: [[Water distribution on Earth]], [[Water resources|Water Resource]]. Out of all the water on [[Earth]], saline water in [[Ocean|oceans]], [[Sea|seas]] and saline [[groundwater]] make up about 97% of it. Only 2.5–2.75% is fresh water, including 1.75–2% frozen in [[Glacier|glaciers]], [[ice]] and [[snow]], 0.5–0.75% as fresh [[groundwater]] and [[soil]] moisture, and less than 0.01% of it as [[surface water]] in [[Lake|lakes]], [[Swamp|swamps]] and [[River|rivers]]. Freshwater lakes contain about 87% of this fresh surface water, including 29% in the [[African Great Lakes]], 22% in [[Lake Baikal]] in Russia, 21% in the [[North American Great Lakes]], and 14% in other lakes. [[Swamp|Swamps]] have most of the balance with only a small amount in rivers, most notably the [[Amazon River]]. The atmosphere contains 0.04% water. In areas with no fresh water on the ground surface, [[fresh water]] derived from [[Precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]] may, because of its lower density, overlie saline ground water in lenses or layers. Most of the world's fresh water is frozen in [[Ice sheet|ice sheets]]. Many areas suffer from lack of distribution of fresh water, such as deserts. == Renewable Internal Freshwater Resources per capita == According to the [http://www.indexmundi.com/about.html Index Mundi]’s data, [[Greenland]] ranked number 1 and [[Iceland]] number 2 in '''renewable internal freshwater resources per capita''' with 10,662,190.00 [[cubic meters]] and 519,264.70 [[cubic meters]], respectively. Renewable internal freshwater resources per capita are calculated using the [[World Bank]]'s population estimates.{{cite web|last1=Mundi|first1=Index|title=Renewable internal freshwater resources per capita|url=http://www.indexmundi.com/facts/indicators/ER.H2O.INTR.PC/rankings|website=IndexMundi|accessdate=2016-11-14|ref=IndexMundi}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- bgcolor="#ececec" ! page.title: List of countries by traffic-related death rate

revision.text:
[[File:Road traffic accidents world map - Death - WHO2013.svg|thumb|upright=2|Death rates from road traffic accidents by country, per 100,000 inhabitants, world map (WHO 2015).Data from [http://www.who.int/violence_injury_prevention/road_safety_status/2015/TableA2.pdf?ua=1 World Health Organization Estimated Deaths 2015]{{#tag:ref|The following groupings/assumptions were made:
*France includes the overseas departments as well as overseas collectivities. *The United Kingdom includes the Crown dependencies as well as the overseas territories. *The United States of America includes the insular areas. *The Netherlands includes Aruba and the Netherlands Antilles. *Denmark includes Greenland and the Faroe islands. *China includes the [[Special administrative region|SARs]] of Hong Kong and Macao. |group="nb"}}
{{div col|colwidth=8em}} {{legend|#ffff65|fewer than 5}} {{legend|#ffdc00|5-10}} {{legend|#ffc600|10-15}} {{legend|#ffb000|15-20}} {{legend|#ff9a00|20-25}} {{legend|#ff6e00|25-30}} {{legend|#ff5800|30-35}} {{legend|#ff2c00|35-40}} {{legend|#cb0000|more than 40}} {{div col end}}]] This '''list of countries by traffic-related death rate''' shows the annual number of road fatalities ''per capita per year'', ''per number of motor vehicles'', and ''per vehicle-km'' in some countries in the year the data was collected. According to the [[World Health Organization]], [[Traffic collision|road traffic injuries]] caused an estimated 1.25 million deaths worldwide in the year 2010. That is, one person is killed every 25 seconds. Only 28 countries, representing 449 million people (seven percent of the world's population), have adequate laws that address all five risk factors (speed, drunk driving, helmets, seat-belts and child restraints). Over a third of road traffic deaths in low- and middle-income countries are among pedestrians and cyclists. However, less than 35 percent of low- and middle-income countries have policies in place to protect these road users.{{cite book |url=http://www.who.int/violence_injury_prevention/road_safety_status/2015/en/ |title=Global Status Report on Road Safety 2015 |publisher=World Health Organisation (WHO) |editor=WHO |pages=vii, 1–14, 75ff (countries), 264–271 (table A2), 316–332 (table A10) |format=PDF |type=official report |location=Geneva|year=2015 |quote=Tables A2 & A10, data from 2013 |isbn=978 92 4 156506 6 |accessdate=2016-01-27}} The average rate was 17.4 per 100,000 people. Low-income countries now have the highest annual road traffic fatality rates, at 24.1 per 100,000, while the rate in high-income countries is lowest, at 9.2 per 100,000. Seventy-four percent of road traffic deaths occur in middle-income countries, which account for only 53 percent of the world's registered vehicles. In low-income countries it is even worse. Only one percent of the world's registered cars produce 16 percent of world's road traffic deaths. This indicates that these countries bear a disproportionately high burden of road traffic deaths relative to their level of motorization. There are large disparities in road traffic death rates between regions. The risk of dying as a result of a road traffic injury is highest in the African Region (increasing 26.6 per 100 000 population), and lowest in the European Region (decreasing 9.3 per 100 000). Half of the world's road traffic deaths occur among motorcyclists (23 percent), pedestrians (22 percent) and cyclists (5 percent) – i.e., "vulnerable road users" – with 31 percent of deaths among car occupants and the remaining 19 percent among unspecified road users.{{cite book |url=http://www.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/78256/1/9789241564564_eng.pdf |title=Global Status Report on Road Safety 2013: supporting a decade of action| publisher=World Health Organisation (WHO)| editor=WHO| pages=vii, 1–8, 53ff (countries), 244–251 (table A2), 296–303 (table A10)| format=PDF| type=official report| location=Geneva, Switzerland| year=2013| quote=Tables A2 & A10, data from 2010| isbn=978 92 4 156456 4| accessdate=2014-05-30}} Adults aged between 15 and 44 years account for 59 percent of global road traffic deaths. Seventy-seven percent of road deaths are males. The total fatalities figures comes from the [[WHO]] report (table A2, column ''point estimate'', pp. 264–271) and are often an adjusted number of road traffic fatalities in order to reflect the different reporting and counting methods among the many countries (e.g., ''"a death after how many days since accident event is still counted as a road fatality?"'' (by international standard adjusted to a 30-day period), or "to compensate for under-reporting in some countries".{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/violence_injury_prevention/road_safety_status/2015/GSRRS2015_data/en/ |title=WHO Report 2015: Data tables |publisher=World Health Organisation (WHO) |editor=WHO |format=PDF |type=official report| location=Geneva|date=2015 |accessdate=2016-01-26}}{{RP|62-74}} ==List== The table shows that the highest death tolls tend to be in African countries, and the lowest in European countries. The table first lists geographic regions before alphabetically sorted countries. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto" |- !
